channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nigeria Is Freeing Children From Boko Haram, Then Locking Them Up
item.media:description: Displaced people taking shelter from the rain at a camp in Maiduguri, Nigeria, in June.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: Civilians, and even infants, are ending up in military detention centers as Nigeria holds people it suspects of being sympathizers of the Islamist extremist group.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Poor Sanitation Persisted at U.N. Missions Long After Haiti Cholera Crisis
item.media:description: A man bathing in the Meye River in Meye, Haiti, in 2012. Studies have traced the 2010 cholera outbreak there to infected United Nations peacekeepers whose fecal waste had leaked into the river.
item.description: Years after the 2010 cholera outbreak in Haiti, auditors found unaddressed public health lapses at the United Nations’ peacekeeping mission there and at other missions.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.N. Leader Urges Member States to Fund Haiti’s Cholera Recovery
item.media:description: Raw sewage and garbage flowed behind homes in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, in 2012. The country’s most important river system was contaminated in 2010, and scientists have blamed peacekeepers from the United Nations.
item.description: Days after acknowledging its role in Haiti’s deadly cholera outbreak, the United Nations is weighing who will pay for the infrastructure necessary to end the epidemic.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN M. KATZ

item.title: Abroad in America: Alienated and Angry, Coal Miners See Donald Trump as Their Only Choice
item.media:description: Miners on the midnight shift at a staging area in the Maple Eagle No. 1 Mine in Powellton, West Virginia. The mine is owned and run by ERP Compliant Fuels.
item.description: Few places in America offer such a simple electoral calculus as West Virginia, where voters support Mr. Trump for his promise to “bring back coal.”
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Afghan Troops Hold Off the Taliban in Kunduz
item.description: Residents fled as insurgents advanced on the city after capturing the nearby Khanabad district.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Pramukh Swami Maharaj, Whose Hindu Sect Became Largest in U.S., Dies at 94
item.media:description: Pramukh Swami Maharaj, center, in Ahmedabad, India, in 2012. In 1971, he became the spiritual leader of the Hindu sect known as BAPS, which he helped expand throughout the world.
item.description: He established more than a thousand temples around the world for BAPS, the Bochasanwasi Akshar Purushottam Swaminarayan Sanstha sect.
item.dc:creator: AYESHA VENKATARAMAN

item.title: An Aging Boy Band Calls It Quits, but Japan Can’t Let Go
item.media:description: The Japanese band SMAP performing with the actress Chiling Lin in Beijing in 2011. The group announced this month that it would be disbanding after decades in the spotlight.
item.media:credit: Li Xueshi/Color China Photo, via AP Images
item.description: The nation is awash with anguish over the announcement of a breakup by SMAP, whose youngest member is now pushing 40.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Russia Asserts Its Military Might in Syria
item.media:description: A cruise missile being launched toward targets in Syria on Friday from a Russian warship in the Mediterranean Sea.
item.media:credit: Ministry of Defence of the Russian Federation, via Reuters
item.description: Warships in the Mediterranean Sea fired cruise missiles days after Russia began bombing runs from a base in Iran.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: More of Kremlin’s Opponents Are Ending Up Dead
item.media:description: The funeral of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a Putin opponent who died of radioactive polonium-210 poisoning in London in 2006.
item.description: Mysterious deaths and close calls have some opposition figures worried that political murder is resurgent in Russian foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Bombing at Wedding Kills at Least 22 in Turkey
item.media:description: Ambulances arriving on Saturday night after an attack on a wedding in Gaziantep, Turkey.
item.description: A bomb targeting a wedding party in southeastern Turkey on Saturday killed at least 22 people and wounded 94 others, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Poverty, Drought and Felled Trees Imperil Malawi Water Supply
item.media:description: Villagers often use wood to bake clay bricks in the Dzalanyama Forest Reserve near Lilongwe, the capital of Malawi, which is experiencing serious water and power shortages. The depletion of the forest has heightened worries.
item.description: The practice of depleting the forest for precious fuel during hard times has been taking a toll at taps in the capital city, Lilongwe.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Australian Premier’s Handout Spurs Debate on Best Way to Help Homeless People
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia placing money into a homeless man’s cup in Melbourne on Wednesday.
item.description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull was criticized after giving a homeless man a few dollars in Melbourne this week, with some deriding it as a photo opportunity at odds with his policies.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: China Helps Aung San Suu Kyi With Peace Talks in Myanmar
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi of Myanmar in Beijing on Thursday. China has persuaded rebel groups to join a peace conference she is convening this month.
item.description: By nudging ethnic rebel groups to participate in a peace conference, China is also aiming to clear the way for commerce across its southern border with Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and WAI MOE

item.title: ‘Night Tube,’ a First for London, Brings All-Night Service to Two Subway Lines
item.media:description: Passengers descending into the Oxford Circus station in central London on Friday night.
item.description: A new 24-hour weekend service opened to the delight of late-night crowds. “People were cheering, ‘Night Tube!’ It seems to be the buzz,” a Tube worker said.
item.dc:creator: PAULINE BOCK

item.title: North Korea Says Diplomat Who Defected Is ‘Human Scum’
item.description: A statement said Thae Yong-ho, the No. 2 person in the London embassy, had fled to South Korea rather than face punishment for various crimes.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Ernst Nolte, Historian Whose Views on Hitler Caused an Uproar, Dies at 93
item.media:description: Ernst Nolte in 2002. He suggested that Nazism was a logical response to the “existential threat” of the Russian Revolution.
item.description: Professor Nolte, a respected German scholar of fascism, suggested in a 1986 essay that Nazism had been a logical response to the “existential threat” of the Russian Revolution.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Ryan Lochte Apologizes ‘For My Behavior’ After Rio Robbery Claim
item.media:description: Reporters at the men’s bathroom at a gas station in Rio de Janeiro where four American Olympic swimmers were captured on security video on Aug. 18.
item.description: Mr. Lochte issued a statement on Instagram saying he should have been “more careful” when giving a disputed account of an armed robbery.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Claim That World Accepts Its Organ Transplant System Is Rebutted
item.media:description: Dr. Philip J. O’Connell, president of the Transplantation Society, said he had told Chinese presenters at a conference that their country’s decades-long practice of using the organs of executed prisoners had horrified the rest of the world.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: The head of the Transplantation Society said that the decades-long practice of using the organs of executed prisoners, which China says has stopped, had horrified the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Happy Warrior in a Faltering Battle for Indonesian Gay Rights
item.media:description: Dede Oetomo is widely considered the godfather of Indonesia’s gay rights movement.
item.description: Dede Oetomo, considered the godfather of Indonesia’s gay rights movement, is fighting a backlash that has turned a long-chilly climate outright hostile.
item.dc:creator: JON EMONT
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Germany, Like France, Questions Place of Islamic Veils in Its Society
item.media:description: There are no official statistics in Germany on the number of women who wear the burqa, which covers the face and body, or the niqab, which covers the hair and face, except for a narrow slit for the eyes. Neither form of attire is seen much on German streets.
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s governing conservative bloc has raised the possibility of a ban on face veils in schools and universities and while driving.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Chilling Tale in Duterte’s Drug War: Father and Son Killed in Police Custody
item.media:description: An investigator near the body of a person accused of dealing drugs in the Novaliches area of greater Manila on Wednesday. Since President Rodrigo Duterte took office, he has pledged to carry out an uncompromising crackdown on crime, including drug suspects.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: Even amid the slaughter of the Filipino president’s war on drugs, the killings of Renato and Jaypee Bertes stand out.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sinosphere: Hong Kong Objects to Alien Presence in Its Skyline (No, Not the Spaceship)
item.description: A poster for the movie “Arrival” depicts an otherworldly craft above Hong Kong’s harbor, but it’s the tower in the foreground that’s really out of place.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Sinosphere: Revamped Chinese History Journal Welcomes Hard-Line Writers
item.media:description: Wang Yanjun, who was ousted as deputy editor of Yanhuang Chunqiu, with the latest issue of the journal on Tuesday, which still shows his name and that of other editors removed by its new managers. Several former editors are trying to sue the journal’s government sponsor to wrest back control.
item.description: The new editors of the magazine, Yanhuang Chunqiu, appear likely to remake what had been one of the few remaining outlets for liberal political opinion in China.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: What in the World: Here’s a New Angle on the Shape of the World
item.description: An Australian statistician has devised a method to rank the world’s nations by how rectangular they are, with Egypt at the head of the class.
item.dc:creator: JAKE DOHERTY

item.title: What in the World: What’s That on Your Bumper? A Hairy Kind of Car Insurance
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photos by Bruno Ferrari, Cammep, ArtHeart/Shutterstock
item.description: Ponytails are attached to taxis for strength and good fortune in West Africa. Religious icons are also popular blessings for safe travel.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Saudi Arabia Kills Civilians, the U.S. Looks the Other Way
item.media:description: A food factory hit by a Saudi-led coalition, killing workers and destroying the building in Sanaa, Yemen, last week.
item.description: Even after a series of deadly attacks that killed Yemeni civilians, Washington’s support remains unwavering.
item.dc:creator: SAMUEL OAKFORD
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: I Criticized the Olympics. That Doesn’t Make Me a Traitor.
item.media:description: People in a nearby favela watched fireworks exploding during the opening ceremonies of the Rio 2016 Olympic Games.
item.description: In Brazil, many of us are so obsessed with how the outside world sees us that we won’t recognize our own faults.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA BARBARA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: When Women Fight ISIS
item.media:description: Kurdish fighters in Tal Hamis, Syria, after it was freed from Islamic State control last year.
item.media:credit: Massoud Mohammed/Barcroft Media, via Getty Images
item.description: Feminists have typically opposed war, but taking up arms is one way for women to defend their communities and to define their place in them.
item.dc:creator: MEREDITH TAX
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Brazil Bureau Chief’s Notebook: When the Olympics Media Circus Comes to Town
item.media:description: Residents of the Mangueira neighborhood in Rio de Janeiro watched fireworks during the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Some of the impressions expressed by journalists parachuting in for the Games call to mind the Onion headline “Woman Who ‘Loves Brazil’ Has Only Seen Four Square Miles of It.”
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Skala Sikaminias Journal: Greek Villagers Rescued Migrants. Now They Are the Ones Suffering.
item.media:description: The keeper of the main church in Skala Sikaminias, Lesbos, looked out to sea. Some villagers say that when they look at the horizon, they often think that another refugee boat is coming.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: The island of Lesbos was ground zero for refugees flooding across the Aegean. A year later, the imprint of that experience still affects one village that tried to help.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
